executive_summary: Long-term trends like globalization, immigration and internet connectivity have continued to usher in revenue growth for language learning software developers. As the US population becomes more diverse, use of language learning apps expands, especially with Spanish-focused courses. Consumers have continued to prefer on-demand, convenient options for self-improvement and learning, which has fueled revenue growth. Industry-wide revenue has climbed at a CAGR of 2.1% to $4.0 billion over the five years to 2023, when revenue will jump by an estimated 4.2%. The COVID-19 pandemic posed some threat to the industry as travel ceased and consumers had no need to learn a language in preparation for vacations overseas. Still, the industry's status as a socially distanced option for self-improvement and mental stimulus helped sustain software producers. Intense competition has forced companies to lower prices and suffer reduced profit. In response, the industry's largest platforms have rolled out AI-powered premium options to help manage fixed costs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While COVID-19 disrupted immigration trends, the growing collaboration between US corporations and overseas partners had upped demand for language learning services from institutional clients. The increasing diversity of the US population has also made knowing a second language a very attractive skill to have when looking for a job, which has driven engagement with language learning software.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consumers Prefer the Convenience of Apps
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Language learning software developers have benefited from growing consumer preference for on-demand language instruction. The flexibility and convenience the industry provides have resonated with consumers, and the growing prevalence of smartphones has provided new markets for language learning apps.

Many consumers specifically learn languages in preparation for upcoming trips abroad, but the onset of COVID-19 halted international travel. Revenue dipped in 2020 as consumers had less reason to spend time learning a new language, but the industry's position as a socially distanced option for language learning helped sustain software developers.

Heightened spare time as work-from-home became the norm left consumers more able to use language learning apps for self-improvement and to keep their brains active. Duolingo's new Duolingo Max is giving premium-tier subscribers a tweaked version of OpenAI's GPT-4 program that's capable of providing adaptive roleplay and language explanation. Other companies like Rosetta Stone and Babbel are also exploring the use of AI in future product rollouts. These new AI assistants are closing the quality gap between in-person and online instruction, which allows language learning software developers to charge higher prices for subscriptions.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Rosetta Stone has continually reported net losses over the past five years and cites intense competition with venture capital-funded start-ups as the primary cause. Low barriers to entry and heavy fragmentation leave room for new entrants to join the industry. Smaller companies will continue to focus on user acquisition and establishing a presence in the market by offering low or free subscription rates and sale prices. This forces established platforms to keep prices low to avoid losing business, which lowers revenue and leaves them with tighter profit.

Rising immigration over the next five years will fuel demand for English programs as migrants seek to better integrate into US neighborhoods. New immigrants most often choose in-person instruction to speed up the process, but many choose cheaper online options. Immigration makes the US population more diverse, which encourages consumers to learn a second language. Immigration also increases the number of legacy speakers, consumers who come from immigrant families that learn their family's language to better connect with their heritage.

Both inbound trips by non-US residents and international trips by US residents will grow at significant rates through the end of 2028. Consumers will more often use language learning apps and websites to prepare for overseas travel. Rising disposable income will help consumers pay for discretionary purchases, like premium subscriptions to language learning platforms.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry develop software that teaches users a foreign language. Companies may provide software-based learning methods as an alternative to classroom instruction or as a supplement. Various software features include speech-recognition technology, online practice sessions with native speakers and language learning games.
key_trends: The US population's increasing diversity makes knowing a language an attractive skill
Increased smartphone use has provided new markets for language learning apps
New AI assistants are closing the quality gap between in-person and online instruction
Low barriers to entry and heavy fragmentation draw in new industry entrants

market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers use language learning platforms to prepare for trips overseas, better connect with an increasingly diverse population, improve their job prospects or a number of other reasons. This segment also includes legacy speakers, the children of immigrants who learn their family's language to better connect with their heritage. One-fifth of the revenue from this segment comes from direct sales of prepackaged software to consumers through Amazon, Best Buy, Barnes and Noble and similar retail point-of-sales.

Schools and higher education institutions purchase language learning software to accelerate learning and make up a larger chunk of revenue for the industry. This segment is more robust and insulated from fluctuations in disposable income, since the use of language software in education is policy driven. Corporations also are using language learning platforms to help conduct business with overseas partners and clients in an increasingly globalized world.

products_and_services.product_description: With the US' proximity to Spanish-speaking countries and a steady influx of immigrants from these countries, Spanish learning programs are the most popular with US consumers.

Many US consumers see French as a refined and sophisticated language, driving enrollment in French learning programs. French programs are more popular in Northeastern states that are near French-speaking regions of Canada.

Strong economic growth in recent years and conflicts abroad have motivated immigrants to relocate to the United States, which drives engagement with English learning programs as migrants seek to better integrate into the United States. However, immigrants seeking to learn English most often do so through in-person instruction to learn more quickly, so this segment accounts for a relatively small share of revenue.

Consumers also learn German, Italian, Mandarin and a variety of other languages as a hobby or as preparation for an upcoming trip. Because of the many languages included in this segment, it accounts for nearly a third of the industry's revenue.

tier_1_suppliers: Database, Storage & Backup Software Publishing in the US
Computer Peripheral Manufacturing in the US
Operating Systems & Productivity Software Publishing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Intellectual Property Licensing in the US
Data Processing & Hosting Services in the US
tier_2_buyers: Finance and Insurance in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Immigration rates and per capita disposable income are factors that influence the size of English as a Second Language (ESL) programs at public and private schools and universities, which often use online language learning platforms. As the size of ESL programs at schools grows, schools and higher education institutions are more inclined to purchase a variety of language learning devices, software and materials.

Along with immigration rates, per capita disposable income influences the level of demand from consumers. Because some software packages come with hefty price tags, consumers will often cancel their subscriptions when money is tight. Still, some online platforms are free-of-charge or carry small subscription fees, insulating the industry from major drops in revenue. Similarly, higher corporate profit encourages corporations to invest in language learning programs for employees. Both consumer and corporate demand are also driven by globalization because it creates incentives to learn a foreign language. While lower pricing encourages consumers to use apps like Babbel and Duolingo, many consumers and institutional clients are willing to pay a premium for high-quality software programs that have solid track records and a reputable brand.

international_trade_points.trade_description: While software developers do engage in international trade, exports and imports of CDs account for a minimal share of revenue and domestic demand, respectively, for language learning software developers. Platforms produced in the United States and downloaded over the internet in foreign countries aren't included in trade figures, and neither are licenses that enable the manufacturing of CDs abroad.

business_locations.location_description: California hosts Silicon Valley, which acts as the nation's largest tech hub. Software developers are much easier to find in Silicon Valley, and the presence of angel investors and venture capitalists in the region also helps facilitate the creation of language learning platforms.
A lack of tech-focused universities in the Plains and Rocky Mountains makes finding capable employees more difficult in these regions.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Software companies protect proprietary information through the use of patents, copyrights, trademarks, trade secret laws, confidentiality procedures and contractual provisions. The Sonny Bono Copyright Term Extension Act of 1998 extended US copyright 70 years beyond the life of the author. The Digital Millennium Copyright Act and the No Electronic Theft Law of 1997 also regulate the use of protected intellectual property in computer programs and online software, even when no monetary profit or commercial gain is derived.

General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is a European Union (EU) regulation that governs the collection and processing of personal data of EU citizens. If US language learning software developers serve customers in the EU or process EU citizens' data, they must comply with GDPR's principles, like obtaining informed consent and providing data protection measures. The Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) also requires software companies to obtain parental consent before collecting personal information from those under 13 years old. The Payment Card Industry Standard also ensures the security of credit and debit cards.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Developing language learning software requires adhering to stringent privacy regulations, such as the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA) and the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).
Creating robust language learning software requires significant investment in research, development and infrastructure.

basis_points.basis_description: Language learning software developers compete on the basis of several factors, mainly product quality, range of products offered and price.
Language learning programs also compete with product and service providers in the larger language learning market.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Because initial investment costs are low, it's fairly easy for new start-ups to join the industry and compete with incumbent language learning programs.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Economies of Scale are Less Helpful
concentration_points.concentration_description: While infrastructure and hardware costs are better managed with a large-scale operation, the industry's reliance on labor reduces the benefits of maximizing a company's size.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit accounts for an estimated 0.6% of revenue in 2023, down from 1.4% in 2018. The wide array of free or low-cost options has driven down prices for most companies, leading major companies like Rosetta Stone to regularly report losses. Newer start-ups like Duolingo and Lesson Nine, operating as Babbel, have only recently implemented a revenue model and are aiming for future profit by first establishing a secure position in the market.

Wage-related expenses account for an estimated 48.8% of revenue in 2023, substantially up from 36.6% in 2018. The average wage is extremely high for this industry as knowledgeable employees capable of bringing about an innovative, user-friendly mobile app or website aren't easy to come by. Intense competition for skilled employees pushes software development companies to offer competitive salaries, and a widespread swell in pay across many industries has pushed wages up even higher.

Purchases comprise an estimated 10.5% of industry revenue in 2023, down from 13.8% in 2018. Since software isn't a tangible good, developers don't need to acquire raw materials and purchases are skewed towards the early phases of creating a language learning platform. Many developers do pay for both server use and hardware, though, which fall under this segment. The small fraction of language learning platforms that still sell their software on CDs have to pay for duplicating and packaging these items, but this segment is declining as the few holdouts switch over to cloud-based instruction.
Depreciation costs make up an estimated 1.8% of revenue in 2023, slightly up from 1.7% in 2018.
Marketing costs make up an estimated 1.8% of revenue in 2023, down from 2.1% in 2018.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Language learning software developers incur a low level of capital intensity. In 2023, for every $1.00 a developer spends on labor, $0.04 is spent on capital investment. Over the five years to 2023, the level of capital intensity has remained steady since the industry has relatively low capital requirements.

Developers need hardware, like computers and servers, as well as software that enables them to build their products. However, server space can be acquired for a small fee and basic software is relatively inexpensive. As a result, it's possible to develop a low-end online language learning program from home.

Labor accounts for a large portion of industry revenue, which further reduces capital intensity. Software developers are highly skilled professionals that are constantly in demand within the technology sector, so wages are high and often are a company's largest expense.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Because instruction in a language is a discretionary expenditure, the industry's success is tied to fluctuations in consumer confidence, per capita disposable income and consumer spending. When consumers are more willing and able to spend their money, language learning software developers benefit from heightened app usage and elevated revenue.

Though the industry usually benefits from relatively stable demand, the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic dampened consumer spending and pushed down revenue for language learning software developers. Pent-up demand resulted in larger jumps in revenue in the years following, translating to heightened volatility from year to year.
Still, the industry was less volatile than its competitors because of its position as an online, socially distanced option for learning a new language.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The most important change for the language learning software development industry has been the transition from CDs to a cloud based-distribution model. Under the cloud-distribution model, programs are distributed via the internet, rather than through a CD, which means the software can be accessed anytime there is an internet connection and used on any computer instead of being limited to a single physical location. Cloud computing also cuts production costs by eliminating the need to produce CDs. Because of this shift, CDs are now a thing of the past and mobile apps are the new standard.

Programming languages have also evolved in recent years. Software developers generally program in a variety of languages including Ruby, Python and Groovy. In recent years, new cutting-edge programming languages have emerged and given programmers new capabilities. In addition, the adoption of the cloud means files can be easily stored and shared, and program development can be done remotely. For example, Cloud9 enables developers to create, edit, test and collaborate on projects via the internet. Programmers can access their code from any computer with an internet connection.

Other technological changes relate to website design and functionality, like seamless transitions and touch screen technology. Developers that operate mobile apps have focused on typography to enhance the readability of text on smartphones and tablets. Over the coming years, as more consumers use smartphones and tablets as opposed to computers, mobile optimization will likely become an increasingly important characteristic in this industry.

FAQs.question: How reliant is your company on advertising revenue?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry generally sell a product or service, and do not generate revenue from advertising. While Duolingo and Babbel offer a free version of their software, they generate revenue through a pay-for-premium model. As apps become increasingly prominent in this industry, the 'freemium' model is expected to become more prevalent in turn.

FAQs.question: How has the shift towards conducting business online affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: The shift online has tremendously helped the industry. The cloud has offered companies a new delivery method, which has contributed to higher subscription sales and lower CD sales.

FAQs.question: Is your company strategically located in a region that acts to your benefit?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the software industry should look West, specifically at California, or in the Northeast, specifically New York City and Boston. These areas generally contain the highest venture capital money and a high concentration of talent.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to rising wages in recent years?
FAQs.answer: As a software industry, companies in this industry compete with the world's largest companies for employees. As a result, wages are highly inflated.

FAQs.question: Has your company prepared adequately to address the increased security risks posed by digital data storage?
FAQs.answer: Generally, industry companies don't hold extremely sensitive personal data. Customers do input their credit card information, which must be protected.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep current with changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: The mobile revolution has spawned mobile-only industry companies. Duolingo and Babbel, for example, are two companies that develop smartphone applications for people that wish to learn new languages.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: On the state and local levels, there are a number of groups that are looking to promote software and technology jobs in their area.

FAQs.question: Have any recent regulatory changes significantly affected your operations?
FAQs.answer: Regulation plays a small role in this industry, as it does throughout software. There is little antitrust worry for the industry at present.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects that require capital financing on the horizon?
FAQs.answer: The industry is not very capital intensive, mainly as a result of high wage costs. If a company want to scale and grow, they may need to bring in investment rather than capital financing. Many of the companies in this industry continue to attract high levels of private investment.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry generally do not generate substantial profit. Rosetta Stone, the largest company, has not seen positive profit since before 2011. Startups, particularly the popular app-based software developers, usually do not focus on profit in the early stage of their life. However, an economic recovery as the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic gradually subsides may boost average industry profit in this industry.

FAQs.question: How much time is invested in research and development? What are the costs associated with this?
FAQs.answer: Developers that invest in research and development produce value-added product extensions and services to maintain their customer base and enter new markets.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? What qualifications must your staff have?
FAQs.answer: Companies that employ highly skilled software developers, marketers and engineers are more likely to produce innovative products.

FAQs.question: What is your current marketing strategy to attract customers? How do your strategies compare with those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Because of the saturated language learning market, operators that effectively market their products and services well benefit from steady and increasing demand.

FAQs.question: How will you be affected by an increase in the number of immigrants coming into the United States? Do you track Number of immigrants
FAQs.answer: While the number of immigrants coming to the United States is expected to rise, the federal government has made immigration policy a priority.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in disposable income? How did you maintain profitability when disposable income declined amid the recession?
FAQs.answer: Since industry products are discretionary and often relatively expensive, demand for industry products is highly dependent on consumers' disposable incomes. Per capita disposable income increased in 2020, due to government stimulus programs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: Is your software compatible with mobile devices? How do you plan to better market your products to smartphone and tablet users?
FAQs.answer: Mobile device-based language learning software is one of the fastest growing segments in the industry.
